title: Transmission Electron Microscopy Characterization of Deformation Features in Refractory High Entropy Alloys
content: Refractory high-entropy alloys (RHEAs) are single phase body-centered cubic (BCC) alloys desired for their high temperature properties, but many are often brittle at room temperature. RHEAs based on Group IV and V elements (IV-V-RHEAs) remain ductile down to liquid nitrogen temperatures [1]. RHEAs are typically designed to be equiatomic compositions, but equiatomic IV-V-RHEAs are unstable in the BCC phase. Zhang et al. [2] developed a thermodynamically stable non-equiatomic RHEA with nominal composition Nb0.45Ta0.25Ti0.15Hf0.15 (at%) (NTTH). NTTH samples tested via compact-tension demonstrate one of the toughest bcc refractory alloys in the literature. Deformation is accompanied by twinning and the formation of low-angle tilt boundaries known as kink bands [1,3]. Kink bands have been observed previously in tension and compression of Group IV-rich RHEAs [1,3,4-7]. However, the role played by kink bands in elevating toughness is not yet established.
